awd_titl_txt: The Exoplanet Frontiers: A Star Ages and M Star Planets
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will support two projects.  The first will determine the ages of relatively hot stars of spectral type A, which have temperatures about twice that of the Sun.  This project relies on accurate determination of stellar radii and temperatures, which will permit comparison between luminosities and evolutionary models of the age/luminosity relation.  The second project aims to discover planets around cool stars of the M type.   The research team will determine accurate positions and radial velocities of these cool stars; the positions and velocities will periodically change if a massive planet is located near the star.

The research will increase the number of stars with precisely determined properties, which should be useful for other research groups and for testing stellar evolution theory and ideas about the formation pf planetary systems.  The project will support two Ph.D. students through the completion of their dissertations, and will contribute to ongoing efforts in public education and outreach.

por.por_cntn:
The research and education activities funded by this grant were focused on searches for low mass companions orbiting nearby M stars, and size measurements of nearby A stars to determine their ages.  Our search for companions to nearby M stars has provided a more complete assessment of the multiplicity of the lowest mass stars, and of our nearest stellar neighbors. Our newly discovered multiple star systems and candidate giant planet hosts may ultimately become valuable benchmarks for testing theories of the structure and evolution of stars and planets.  Our improved understanding of these nearest stellar neighbors has helped identify which are well suited for ultra-precise exoplanet searches targeting Earth-like planets in the habitable zone. This longer-term goal is a recommended objective of the New Worlds New Horizons 2010 Astronomy Decadal Survey.
Our program to determine A star ages has greatly improved age estimates of these nearby bright stellar neighbors, some of which harbor debris disks and other which host candidate exoplanets.  These improved timestamps thus offer valuable constraints on the temporal evolution of disks and planets.  We have also developed a more sophisticated technique that allows us to account for the distorted shape and gravity darkening of rapidly rotating A stars. This has allowed us to not only improve age estimates for rapid rotators, but to test stellar models that account for rotation and to improve age estimates for nearby star clusters and moving groups.
This program has enable the PI to advise 1 undergraduate student and the PhD thesis work of 6 graduate students.  All members of this research group have regularly volunteered to share the exciting discoveries of this work and astronomy in general to the public through outreach events, especially those at Georgia State University's Hard Labor Creek Observatory.
